document.docAuthor: Shaw, Scott R., Marsh, Paul M. & Fortier, Joseph C.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of Nearctic Aleiodes Wesmael (Part 8): the coxalis (Spinola) Species­Group (Hymenoptera: Braconidae, Rogadinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of Nearctic Aleiodes Wesmael (Part 8): the coxalis (Spinola) Species­Group (Hymenoptera: Braconidae, Rogadinae)

heading.emphasis:
Key to Nearctic species of the
Coxalis
species­group

paragraph.keyLead:
3 ( 2 ). Body length 4–6 mm ; head and mesosoma usually with black markings; fore wing stigma usually medium to dark brown (
Figs. 4
, 15 ,
22
) .............................................
....................................................................................... sanctihyacinthi
(Provancher)

­ Body length 8–9 mm ; body entirely honey yellow; fore wing stigma usually yellow or light brown (
Fig. 10
)
........................................................... whartoni
NEW SPECIES

4 ( 2 ). Fore wing vein 1 cu­a beyond 1 M by distance less than length of 1 cu­a, thus 1 cu­a longer than 1 CUa (
Figs. 1, 2
,
18
)
.......................................... aquilonius
NEW SPECIES
­ Fore wing vein 1 cu­a beyond 1 M by distance equal to or greater than length of 1 cu­ a, thus 1 cu­a equal to or shorter than 1 CUa............................................................... 5

5 ( 4 ). Legs brown, mesonotum orange ...........................................
floridensis
NEW SPECIES

6 ( 5 ). Hind wing vein m­cu a distinct tubular vein for most of its length and nearly as long as vein cu­a; first metasomal tergum rugose coriaceous (
Figs. 8
, 19 ).........................
........................................................................................ itamevorus
Shaw and Marsh

­ Hind wing vein m­cu represented by short fuscous line or nebulous vein; first meta­ somal tergum rugose costate
........................................... maritimus
Shaw and Marsh

7 ( 1 ). Fore wing second submarginal cell short, forming a short rectangle or nearly square (
Fig. 21
).................................................................................
quadratus
NEW SPECIES

keyStep.paragraph:
mesosoma black, at most with mesonotum and pronotum orange (
Fig. 5
) ................
............................................................................................ dichromatus
NEW SPECIES
­ Metasoma entirely orange or yellow, rarely with apical terga darker, particularly in males; mesosoma orange or yellow, rarely marked with black (
Fig. 3
) .................... 9

paragraph.keyLead:
9 ( 8 ). Median length of pronotum greater than either the ocell­ocular distance or the ength of first flagellomere (
Fig. 11
)
........................................... aciculatus
Cresson

10 ( 9 ).Metasomal terga 1–3 distinctly costate or with parallel longitudinal ridges separated by deep sulcations (
Fig. 3
)
............................................................ brevis
NEW SPECIES

11 ( 10 ).Length of second metasomal tergum equal to or longer than basal width, first metasomal tergum longer than apical width (
Figs. 27–28
)
........... shenefelti
NEW SPECIES

12 ( 11 ).Mesosoma honey yellow; mesonotum weakly coriaceous, appearing nearly smooth and shining; antenna with more than 35 antennomeres
......... cultrarius
NEW SPECIES

­ Mesosoma orange marked with black; mesonotum strongly coriaceous; antenna with less than 35 antennomeres (
Fig. 7
)
......................... wyomingensis
NEW SPECIES
